attributes.description:
To perform a component-level compliance assessment for CCI-001459, you must verify that the content of audit records is centrally managed. [cite: 17]

**How to Assess Compliance:**

1.  [cite_start]**Use Global Filters:** At the top of the dashboard, apply filters to narrow your focus. [cite: 18] [cite_start]To assess a specific component, use a filter like `host.name: <your_component_name>`. [cite: 19]

2.  [cite_start]**Review the Inventory:** Start with the 'Audit Source Inventory' table to confirm that every required system component is running an approved audit agent (e.g., Auditbeat, Winlogbeat, or Elastic Agent). [cite: 20]

3.  [cite_start]**Check for Consistency:** Use the 'Audit Configuration Consistency' chart to spot deviations. [cite: 21] [cite_start]If all systems are centrally managed, their configurations (represented by the colored bars) should be identical. [cite: 22] [cite_start]Any host that looks different from the baseline has likely drifted from the central policy and requires investigation. [cite: 23]

4.  [cite_start]**Verify Management Type:** The 'Audit Agent Management Type' chart shows if agents are managed by a tool like Elastic Fleet ('elastic-agent'). [cite: 24] [cite_start]A large number of legacy agents ('auditbeat', 'winlogbeat') may indicate manual, decentralized management, which could be a compliance risk. [cite: 25]
attributes.title: [CCI-001459] Audit Generation
attributes.visState: {"title":"[CCI-001459] Audit Generation","type":"markdown","aggs":[],"params":{"markdown":"# [CCI-001459] Audit Generation\n\n### Centrally manage audit record content.","fontSize":12,"openLinksInNewTab":false}}

attributes.description:
**Why and When:** Use this table to investigate configuration drift anomalies flagged in the trend chart. It helps you pinpoint exactly which host has deviated from the centrally managed baseline, which is a key requirement of CCI-001459.

**How to Use:** Filter by time to focus on a specific anomaly. The `over_field_value` shows the anomalous host, and the `partition_field_value` shows the audit module that is unusual for that host. This allows you to quickly identify systems that need to be brought back into compliance with the standard configuration.
attributes.title: [AU-12, CCI-001459] ML - Detailed Config Drift Anomalies

attributes.description:
This table provides a complete inventory of all deployed audit agents and the hosts they are running on.

**Why and when this visualization works:**
This is your starting point for the compliance check. It gives you a baseline of what audit capabilities are deployed across your infrastructure. Use it to quickly identify if critical systems are missing an audit agent entirely. [cite: 15]

**How an analyst can use it:**
1.  [cite_start]Scan the `host.name` column to ensure all in-scope systems are present. [cite: 15]
2.  [cite_start]Review the `agent.type` and `event.module` columns to verify that the correct type of auditing is active on each host (e.g., `auditbeat` for Linux, `winlogbeat` for Windows). [cite: 15, 16]
3.  Filter for a specific host to drill down into its particular configuration. [cite_start]Any host that is expected to be generating audit logs but is missing from this table is a potential compliance finding. [cite: 16]

kibanaSavedObjectMeta.searchSourceJSON: {"query":{"language":"kuery","query":"(event.module : (auditd or winlogbeat or sysmon or system or security) or agent.type : (auditbeat or winlogbeat or osquery or elastic-agent or filebeat) or event.dataset : (*.audit_log or *.security or \"aws.cloudtrail\" or \"azure.activitylogs\" or \"gcp.audit\" or \"k8s.audit\") or process.name : (auditd or rsyslogd or \"syslog-ng\" or nxlogd))"},"filter":[],"indexRefName":"kibanaSavedObjectMeta.searchSourceJSON.index"}

attributes.title: [CCI-001459] Audit Source Inventory

attributes.description:
This chart visualizes the specific audit modules enabled on each host, making it easy to spot inconsistencies.

**Why and when this visualization works:**
This is the most direct way to visually verify 'central management'. [cite: 26] If systems are managed by a central policy, their configurations should be identical. [cite_start]This chart makes any deviation immediately obvious. [cite: 26] [cite_start]Use this after confirming the basic inventory to check for configuration drift. [cite: 27]

**How an analyst can use it:**
1. [cite_start]Look for uniformity. [cite: 27] [cite_start]The colored bars representing different `event.module` values should appear in the same pattern for each host. [cite: 28]
2.  [cite_start]Identify any host that has a different pattern of colors. [cite: 29] [cite_start]This indicates its configuration does not match the baseline and has 'drifted'. [cite: 30]
3.  [cite_start]Hover over any bar segment to see the specific module and the event count. [cite: 31]
4.  [cite_start]A host with a different configuration must be investigated to determine if the change was unauthorized, as it violates the principle of central management. [cite: 32]

query.query: (event.module : (auditd or winlogbeat or sysmon or system or security) or agent.type : (auditbeat or winlogbeat or osquery or elastic-agent or filebeat) or event.dataset : (*.audit_log or *.security or \"aws.cloudtrail\" or \"azure.activitylogs\" or \"gcp.audit\" or \"k8s.audit\") or process.name : (auditd or rsyslogd or \"syslog-ng\" or nxlogd))

attributes.title: [CCI-001459] Audit Configuration Consistency

attributes.description:
This chart provides a high-level overview of how your audit agents are managed across the environment.

**Why and when this visualization works:**
It helps you quickly determine if a central management tool, like Elastic Fleet, is the primary method for agent deployment and configuration. [cite: 33] [cite_start]A system relying on central management will have a more uniform and compliant posture. [cite: 33]

**How an analyst can use it:**
1.  Observe the breakdown of agent types. [cite_start]A high percentage of `elastic-agent` strongly suggests central management via Fleet. [cite: 34]
2.  [cite_start]A significant presence of legacy agents (`auditbeat`, `winlogbeat`, etc.) may indicate that configurations are managed manually on a host-by-host basis. [cite: 35] [cite_start]While not necessarily non-compliant, manual management increases the risk of configuration drift and should be scrutinized more closely using the other visualizations. [cite: 36]

query.query: agent.type:* and agent.type:(elastic-agent or *beat or osquery)

attributes.title: [CCI-001459] Audit Agent Management Type

attributes.description: This visualization displays the health status of central audit management for CCI-001459 based on the anomaly scores from the associated ML job. A high score indicates a host's audit configuration has drifted from the population norm, signaling a potential compliance issue.
attributes.title: [CCI-001459] Audit Generation ML

This directly supports the requirements of CCI-001459, which mandates the generation of audit records for logon events.

**Why and When:** This is a crucial visualization for monitoring access control and identifying potential brute-force or password-spraying attacks. A sudden, large spike in 'failure' outcomes is a strong indicator of malicious activity. Consistent, low-level failures from a specific host could point to a misconfigured service account.

**How to Use:** Monitor the trend lines for anomalies. The 'success' line should follow predictable patterns based on your organization's business hours. The 'failure' line should ideally be flat and close to zero. Use the time selector to zoom in on suspicious spikes. You can also filter by 'host.name' to see logon activity for a single machine, helping you verify that it is correctly generating logon audit CCI-001459] ML - Config Drift Anomaly Score Trend (converted)","description":"**Why and When:** This chart addresses CCI-001459 by detecting configuration drift. The ML job learns the population norm for audit configurations (e.g., which agents or modules are running on servers). An anomaly score spike indicates that a host's audit configuration has deviated from the established baseline, which could be an unauthorized change or a failed deployment, both of which violate central management principles.

**How to Use:** Monitor for spikes in the anomaly score. A high score indicates a host is behaving differently from its peers. Use the time selector to zoom in on the anomaly, then investigate the 'Detailed Config Drift Anomalies' table to see which host and module are
